David Bailie  
---  
Born | (1937-12-04) 4 December 1937 (age 80)  
Springs, South Africa  
Occupation | Actor, photographer, videographer, computer programmer, furniture maker/designer  
Years active | 1961–present  
Spouse(s) | Egidija Bailie (m. 2002)  
Website | <http://davidbailie.co.uk/>  
  
**David Bailie** (born 4 December 1937)[1] is an English actor, known for his
performances on stage, television and film. In the 1960s and 1970s he worked
for both the National Theatre and the Royal Shakespeare Company, where he was
an associate artist. On TV he played "Dask" in the 1977 _[Doctor
Who](/wiki/Doctor_Who "Doctor Who")_ serial _[The Robots of
Death](/wiki/The_Robots_of_Death "The Robots of Death")_ , and also appeared
in _[Blake's 7](/wiki/Blake%27s_7 "Blake's 7")_. On film, he played the mute
pirate
[Cotton](/wiki/List_of_minor_characters_in_Pirates_of_the_Caribbean#Cotton_and_his_Parrot
"List of minor characters in Pirates of the Caribbean") in the [_Pirates of
the Caribbean_ series](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean_\(film_series\) "Pirates
of the Caribbean \(film series\)").[2] Bailie is also a professional
photographer, specialising in portrait photography. He has a studio in [West
Kensington](/wiki/West_Kensington "West Kensington"), London.

## Life and
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=David_Bailie&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Life and career")]

Bailie was born in Springs, South Africa, and went to boarding school in
[Swaziland](/wiki/Swaziland "Swaziland"), before emigrating to
[Rhodesia](/wiki/Rhodesia "Rhodesia") (now [Zimbabwe](/wiki/Zimbabwe
"Zimbabwe")) with his family in 1952. His first acting experience soon after
school in 1955 was an amateur production of _[Doctor in the
House](/wiki/Doctor_in_the_House "Doctor in the House")_ , which persuaded him
he wanted to be an actor.[3] After leaving school he worked in a bank and then
for Central African Airlines. In 1958, he made his first trip from Rhodesia to
[Britain](/wiki/UK "UK").

In 1960 he moved to Britain and landed his first small role in the film
_[Flame in the Streets](/wiki/Flame_in_the_Streets "Flame in the Streets")_
(1961) and then played one of the [bell boys](/wiki/Bellhop "Bellhop") in
[Arthur Kopit](/wiki/Arthur_Kopit "Arthur Kopit")'s _[Oh Dad, Poor Dad,
Mamma's Hung You in the Closet and I'm Feelin' So
Sad](/wiki/Oh_Dad,_Poor_Dad,_Mamma%27s_Hung_You_in_the_Closet_and_I%27m_Feelin%27_So_Sad
"Oh Dad, Poor Dad, Mamma's Hung You in the Closet and I'm Feelin' So Sad")_
(1961) with [Stella Adler](/wiki/Stella_Adler "Stella Adler") playing Madame
Rosepettle. He then bluffed his way into weekly [repertory](/wiki/Repertory
"Repertory") in [Barrow-in-Furness](/wiki/Barrow-in-Furness "Barrow-in-
Furness") as juvenile lead – terrified the while that he would be exposed as
totally inexperienced.

Recognising the need for training, he auditioned three times for a bursary to
the [RADA](/wiki/Royal_Academy_of_Dramatic_Art "Royal Academy of Dramatic
Art")—each time being accepted only as a fee-paying student, which he couldn't
afford. He finally sent for the last of his standby money (£200) he had left
in Rhodesia and paid for the first term (1963). At the end of term he
persuaded John Fernald to allow him free tuition for the next two years.

[Terry Hands](/wiki/Terry_Hands "Terry Hands") was also a student at the same
time, but had left a little earlier than Bailie and formed the [Everyman
Theatre](/wiki/Everyman_Theatre,_Liverpool "Everyman Theatre, Liverpool") with
Peter James in Liverpool. On leaving RADA Bailie was invited to join the
Everyman in 1964. Amongst other roles he played "Tolen" in _[The
Knack...](/wiki/The_Knack_...and_How_to_Get_It "The Knack ...and How to Get
It")_ , "Becket" in _[Murder in the Cathedral](/wiki/Murder_in_the_Cathedral
"Murder in the Cathedral")_ , "Dion" in _[The Great God
Brown](/wiki/The_Great_God_Brown "The Great God Brown")_ ,
"[MacDuff](/wiki/Macduff_\(Macbeth\) "Macduff \(Macbeth\)")" in
_[Macbeth](/wiki/Macbeth "Macbeth")_ and
"[Lucky](/wiki/Lucky_\(Waiting_for_Godot\) "Lucky \(Waiting for Godot\)")" in
_[Waiting for Godot](/wiki/Waiting_for_Godot "Waiting for Godot")_.

After a year there, he came back to London and auditioned for and was accepted
by Sir [Laurence Olivier](/wiki/Laurence_Olivier "Laurence Olivier") joining
the [National Theatre](/wiki/Royal_National_Theatre "Royal National Theatre").
He played minor roles and also understudied Olivier in _Love for Love_.

Terry Hands, who had by now joined the [Royal Shakespeare
Company](/wiki/Royal_Shakespeare_Company "Royal Shakespeare Company") (RSC) at
[Stratford-upon-Avon](/wiki/Stratford-upon-Avon "Stratford-upon-Avon") (and
later became its artistic director), invited Bailie to join them as an
associate artist (1965). There he portrayed "Florizel" opposite [Judi
Dench](/wiki/Judi_Dench "Judi Dench")'s "Perdita" in _[The Winter's
Tale](/wiki/The_Winter%27s_Tale "The Winter's Tale")_ along with "Valentine"
in _[The Two Gentlemen of Verona](/wiki/The_Two_Gentlemen_of_Verona "The Two
Gentlemen of Verona")_ , "The Bastard" in _[King
John](/wiki/The_Life_and_Death_of_King_John "The Life and Death of King
John")_ , "Kozanka" in _The Plebeians Rehearse the Uprising_ and "Leslie" in
_[The Madness of Lady Bright](/wiki/The_Madness_of_Lady_Bright "The Madness of
Lady Bright")_.

During the early 1970s he worked with [Stomu Yamashta](/wiki/Stomu_Yamashta
"Stomu Yamashta") at his Red Buddha Theatre. He was cast as the lead in a show
called _Raindog_ , requiring him to do everything from singing and dancing, to
performing Martial Arts and gymnastics – which he frankly admits been a demand
too far and when Yamashta offered him a paltry sum for performing the
opportunity was there to depart which he did. He was then cast by [Michael E.
Briant](/wiki/Michael_E._Briant "Michael E. Briant") in 1976 to play the part
of the villain "Dask" in the _[Doctor Who](/wiki/Doctor_Who "Doctor Who")_
serial _[The Robots of Death](/wiki/The_Robots_of_Death "The Robots of
Death")_.[4] He also played in a number of other series prominent at the time.

For personal reasons Bailie then had a long recess in his acting career.
Between 1980 and 1989 he ran a furniture-making business. In 1990 he closed
that down and returned to acting, having in fact to virtually restart his
career. It didn't help that at exactly this point he had to have a cancer
removed from his lip, which required learning to speak again. Whilst awaiting
work in the acting field he busied himself with CAD design, self-training and
writing computer programs and also doing health and safety work in the
building industry.

In the mid-1990s after playing alongside [Brian Glover](/wiki/Brian_Glover
"Brian Glover") in _[The Canterbury Tales](/wiki/The_Canterbury_Tales "The
Canterbury Tales")_ he made a comeback in the film business as "Skewer" in
_[Cutthroat Island](/wiki/Cutthroat_Island "Cutthroat Island")_ (1995), then
played an English Judge in _[The Messenger: The Story of Joan of
Arc](/wiki/The_Messenger:_The_Story_of_Joan_of_Arc "The Messenger: The Story
of Joan of Arc")_ (1999), and also "The Engineer" in
_[Gladiator](/wiki/Gladiator_\(2000_film\) "Gladiator \(2000 film\)")_ (2000).

Bailie's best-known work in film is the role of "Cotton", a mute pirate who
has his tongue cut out, so he trained his parrot, also named Cotton, to speak
on his behalf, though it cannot say more than stock phrases. Bailie first
appears as Cotton in _[Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black
Pearl](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_The_Curse_of_the_Black_Pearl "Pirates
of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl")_ (2003) as one of the pirates
[Jack Sparrow](/wiki/Jack_Sparrow "Jack Sparrow") chooses in Tortuga. He is
one of the _Black Pearl_ crewmembers to survive the
[Kraken](/wiki/Kraken_\(Pirates_of_the_Caribbean\) "Kraken \(Pirates of the
Caribbean\)") attack in the sequel _[Dead Man's
Chest](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_Dead_Man%27s_Chest "Pirates of the
Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest")_ (2006), and also played Cotton in the third
instalment: _[At World's End](/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean:_At_World%27s_End
"Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End")_ (2007).

Bailie also emerged as a radio actor. He played the mad scientist "Taren
Capel", a re-incarnation of his earlier work from the 60s series _Doctor Who_.
He has recently been involved in two [Big Finish
Productions](/wiki/Big_Finish_Productions "Big Finish Productions") audio
dramas playing the "[Celestial Toymaker](/wiki/Celestial_Toymaker "Celestial
Toymaker")".

Bailie also works as a professional photographer, portraiture and landscapes
being his speciality.[5]

He has established a YouTube channel _**mdebailes**_ to which he uploads
readings and performance excerpts.

qa.question: who played cotton in pirates of the caribbean

nq_1593_1.Query Analysis: The query asks for the name of the actor who played the character Cotton in the 'Pirates of the Caribbean' film series.
nq_1593_1.Query Keywords Extraction: played, Cotton, Pirates of the Caribbean
